papers.abstract: Protein and peptide engineering has become an essential field in biomedicine with therapeutics, diagnostics and synthetic biology applications. Helices are both abundant structural feature in proteins and comprise a major portion of bioactive peptides. Precise design of helices for binding or biological activity is still a challenging problem. Here, we present HelixGAN, the first generative adversarial network method to generate de novo left-handed and right-handed alpha-helix structures from scratch at an atomic level. We developed a gradient-based search approach in latent space to optimize the generation of novel α-helical structures by matching the exact conformations of selected hotspot residues. The designed α-helical structures can bind specific targets or activate cellular receptors. There is a significant agreement between the helix structures generated with HelixGAN and PEP-FOLD, a well-known de novo approach for predicting peptide structures from amino acid sequences. HelixGAN outperformed RosettaDesign, and our previously developed structural similarity method to generate D-peptides matching a set of given hotspots in a known L-peptide. As proof of concept, we designed a novel D-GLP1_1 analog that matches the conformations of critical hotspots for the GLP1 function. MD simulations revealed a stable binding mode of the D-GLP1_1 analog coupled to the GLP1 receptor. This novel D-peptide analog is more stable than our previous D-GLP1 design along the MD simulations. We envision HelixGAN as a critical tool for designing novel bioactive peptides with specific properties in the early stages of drug discovery.

events.Text: Here, we present HelixGAN, the first generative adversarial network method to generate de novo left-handed and right-handed alpha-helix structures from scratch at an atomic level. We developed a gradient-based search approach in latent space to optimize the generation of novel α-helical structures by matching the exact conformations of selected hotspot residues.

Agent: We developed a gradient-based search approach in latent space to optimize the generation of novel α-helical structures by matching the exact conformations of selected hotspot residues.

Primary Object: HelixGAN is presented as the first GAN method to generate de novo left-handed and right-handed alpha-helix structures from scratch at an atomic level.
Secondary Object: A gradient-based search approach in latent space was employed to optimize the generation process.

Context: This work introduces HelixGAN, highlighting its uniqueness among GANs for generating precise helical structures.
They emphasize the development of a novel methodology involving a gradient-based search in latent space aimed at creating accurate helices.
The innovation focuses on generating helices specifically targeted at hotspot residues to match exact conformations.
Purpose: To introduce HelixGAN as the first GAN capable of generating diverse alpha-helical structures from scratch.
To develop a new optimization strategy utilizing gradient-based searches in latent spaces for structural accuracy.
Method: Optimization via matching conformations of hotspot residues in latent space.
Results: Generation of de novo left-handed and right-handed alpha-helical structures at an atomic level successfully demonstrated by HelixGAN.
Novel α-helical structures were created by precisely matching hotspot residue conformations.
Analysis: HelixGAN addresses the gap in current GAN capabilities regarding helical structure specificity.
The method leverages advanced optimization techniques for improved structural fidelity.
Challenge: Potential limitation lies in computational complexity due to high-dimensional latent space operations.
Scalability issues may arise given the detailed modeling required for atomic-level precision.
Ethical: No explicit ethical concerns discussed; however, such advancements raise questions about data privacy and usage restrictions.
Assumptions made during model training require consideration of user intent and adherence to guidelines.
Implications: Significant advancement in molecular modeling and drug discovery potentials.
Could lead to breakthroughs in understanding protein folding mechanisms and designing therapeutics.
Contradictions: No contradictions identified with established biological principles or prior studies.

papers.abstract: Reliable label-free methods are needed for detecting and profiling apoptotic events in time-lapse cell-cell interaction assays. Prior studies relied on fluorescent markers of apoptosis, e.g. Annexin-V, that provide an inconsistent and late indication of apoptotic onset for human melanoma cells. Our motivation is to improve the detection of apoptosis by directly detecting apoptotic bodies in a label-free manner. Our trained ResNet50 network identified nanowells containing apoptotic bodies with 92% accuracy and predicted the onset of apoptosis with an error of one frame (5 min/frame). Our apoptotic body segmentation yielded an IoU accuracy of 75%, allowing associative identification of apoptotic cells. Our method detected apoptosis events, 70% of which were not detected by Annexin-V staining.

Prior studies relied on fluorescent markers of apoptosis, e.g. Annexin-V, that provide an inconsistent and late indication of apoptotic onset for human melanoma cells. Our motivation is to improve the detection of apoptosis by directly detecting apoptotic bodies in a label-free manner.

Our trained ResNet50 network identified nanowells containing apoptotic bodies with 92% accuracy and predicted the onset of apoptosis with an error of one frame (5 min/frame). Our apoptotic body segmentation yielded an IoU accuracy of 75%, allowing associative identification of apoptotic cells.

providing accurate predictions based on visual features
